description.narrative: The overall objective of this project is to introduce a set of comprehensive measures that will significantly improve the Prespa Lake’s overall health, strengthen its resilience, and ensure, in the long-run, control of the eutrophication processes.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: At least 8% reduction of nutrient loads (and other substances) to the lake as a result of the gradual increase of project supported measures % of hectares under Good Agricultural Practices and/or agro-ecological measures $ of area under nature-based systems (wetlands, river corridors, buffers) Quantity of collected pesticide packaging and biodegradable waste Functional Watershed Management Committee as a formal cross-sectoral participatory mechanism for integrated watershed management # of knowledge products (manuals, guidance documents, lessons learnt booklets, fact sheets and articles)

comment.narrative: High proportion of the delineated water bodies in the Prespa Lake watershed doesn’t meet the requirement of having ‘good’ ecological status according to the existing regulations Important natural landscape elements (ecotones) are being destroyed over the past decades as a result of development pressures The current nutrient loads of anthropogenic origin (500 t/year) exceed the levels the lake ecosystem can absorb without further degrading Unsustainable farming practices, especially overuse of pesticides, fertilizers and irrigation water No sufficient monitoring and management capacities exist at present The current organizational structure and capacity of Municipality of Resen and other responsible organizations / institutions doesn’t meet the needs of an integrated watershed management system Low level of awareness about nature protection and sustainable use of natural resources

Finalization of the eutrophication model and user training on model application; User training on model application (Output 1.1)
Locally implemented forest regeneration activities in priority erosion areas with plant material produced at project-backed the forest nursery (Output 1.2)
Completion of all three cycles of the grants programme to support agro-ecological farming practices; Finalization of the feasibility study on irrigation options for the Prespa Lake Basin (Output 1.3)
Launching wetland restoration activities (Output 1.4)
Continuation of operation of the composting plant in Resen (Output 1.5)
Completion of all initiated small-scale environmental/water infrastructure projects (Output 1.7)
Completion of the pilot monitoring programme (by the Hydrobiological Institute) and continuation of regular monitoring programme by the Lake Monitoring Station (Output 2.1)
Delivery of upgraded/advanced capacity development programme for the representatives of the new Sector on Environment (Output 2.2)
Support exchanges and partnering with the existing relevant professional networks and lake regions (Output 2.3)

1. The eutrophication modeling has been completed, including the advanced simulations of possible changes to watershed phosphorus loading taking into consideration projected future climate conditions. Coupled with the ongoing training programme for municipal personnel, these efforts will enable the future use of the model as a significant decision-support system informing future strategies, and development plans for the watershed. 2. Following the initial forest regeneration activities implemented earlier in 2015, the Public Forest Enterprise continued with similar action on an additional area of approximately 30 hectares of eroded land (75 hectares of eroded land were reforested in total in 2015 with over 400,000 trees). The planting material produced at the project-supported native forest nursery is used for this purpose. This has positive economic effects for the Public Forest Enterprise that is now able to save nearly 20,000 USD per year. 3. Thanks to the earlier training and on-demand technical assistance, the 77 selected grantees managed to significantly improve farming practices in their pilot orchards in a combined area of approximately 76 hectares. The positive effects of the use of the new practices may be illustrated by the following examples: a) the use of irrigation water on the pilot orchards is by 60% lower compared to earlier irrigation practices; b) there is 40-50% reduction in the application of phosphorus and nitrogen based fertilizers as a result of the more balanced nutrition. As a result, about 65 tons of annual phosphorus and 5 tons of annual nitrogen loading has been kept out of water bodies thanks to modern farming practices implemented at the pilot apple orchards alone. Municipal estimates say that the modern farming practices have been extended to an additional area of approximately 1,000 hectares of apple orchards. 4. Following the completion of the necessary preparatory activities (e.g., restoration design and review stage, communication with the local communities, procurement procedures), the wetland restoration activities were initiated within the Ezerani Nature Park. The overall progress and implementation intensity of the restoration activities are slowed down for two key, mainly politically-driven reasons: a) delays in obtaining consent by the Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning; b) opposition of part of the local community due to their concerns over the speculations for possible increase of flooding risk as a result of the project. The prolonged unpredictable political situation in the country and the election period amplify these challenges and inhibits the efforts of official institutions to deal with such issues. However, commitment of all relevant partners to the realization of this project activity still remains high and constant efforts are being made to improve implementation efficiency and complete the restoration plan. 5. Thanks to the improved efficiency of composting plant’s operation, increasing quantities of organic waste material are being processed (minimum 2,000 t organic waste annually) into a high-value compost, preventing at the same time organic loading to water bodies. The composting plant already represents a national/regional model for biodegradable waste management. The experiences and lessons learnt are shared within and outside the country. Additional support aiming at increasing the capacity and procession efficiency of the plant will be provided through the project component that will be implemented by the Municipality of Resen. 6. All eleven selected small-scale water/environmental infrastructure projects have been completed, some of them ahead of the anticipated deadline. As a result over 5,000 people are benefiting directly from the improved water supply and sanitation, improved irrigation efficiency, removed dumpsites and newly created recreational areas. As part of this programme, the following small-scale infrastructure projects were completed: five water supply systems (Jankovec, Nakolec, Dolno Dupeni and two in Resen), two dumpsite remediation/eco-parks projects (Krani and Strbovo), one integrated sewerage and stormwater drainage solution (Resen), and two irrigation systems (Kurbinovo and Krani). 7. The Hydrobiological Institute – hired to provide expert support to LMS - completed the pilot monitoring programme. The Lake Monitoring Station (LMS) in Stenje has taken over the key role in the regular monitoring of Lake Prespa and its tributaries thanks to the on-the-job training of the hired local personnel and combined financing secured by the project and the Municipality of Resen. The financing of LMS is to a great extent secured by the municipality’s savings from the project-supported energy efficiency measures. 8. The personnel from the Sector on Environment is continuously undergoing different trainings on relevant topics, either organized by the project or by other complementary projects/initiatives (e.g., Bregalnica and Strumica River Basin projects, IPA projects on NATURA 2000, and other). The Municipality of Resen is pursuing the procedures for hiring the necessary staff of the Sector on Environment, some of which were previously project supported. So far, the three park rangers and the technician at the LMS have been employed regularly, while the procedures for the two new personnel (one from LMS and other from the Natural Capital Resource Center) are underway. Based on the information from the Municipality, these employments are expected to be completed by the end of the year or early in 2017. The personnel from LMS and the Natural Capital Resource Center are already contracted by the municipality but on a temporary basis, which needs to be transformed into permanent contracts. 9. The project continues implementing its communication and outreach programmes as planned. The media coverage of the project still remains high, besides that the project is in the mature stages of implementation, and the number of ongoing activities is reducing over time. The project actively participates in all relevant national level processes in the specific programmatic areas (e.g., water management, waste management, monitoring, and WFD implementation). In order to better systematize and promote results, the project is working both on final publication and a documentary film. These products are expected to be completed by the end of 2016, along with a plan for their international and national promotion.

Finalization of the eutrophication model and user training on model application; User training on model application (Output 1.1)
Locally implemented forest regeneration activities in priority erosion areas with plant material produced at project-backed the forest nursery (Output 1.2)
Completion of all three cycles of the grants programme to support agro-ecological farming practices; Finalization of the feasibility study on irrigation options for the Prespa Lake Basin (Output 1.3)
Launching wetland restoration activities (Output 1.4)
Continuation of operation of the composting plant in Resen (Output 1.5)
Completion of all initiated small-scale environmental/water infrastructure projects (Output 1.7)
Completion of the pilot monitoring programme (by the Hydrobiological Institute) and continuation of regular monitoring programme by the Lake Monitoring Station (Output 2.1)
Delivery of upgraded/advanced capacity development programme for the representatives of the new Sector on Environment (Output 2.2)
Support exchanges and partnering with the existing relevant professional networks and lake regions (Output 2.3)

The financing of LMS is to a great extent secured by the municipality’s savings from the project-supported energy efficiency measures. 8. The personnel from the Sector on Environment is continuously undergoing different trainings on relevant topics, either organized by the project or by other complementary projects/initiatives (e.g., Bregalnica and Strumica River Basin projects, IPA projects on NATURA 2000, and other). The Municipality of Resen is pursuing the procedures for hiring the necessary staff of the Sector on Environment, some of which were previously project supported. So far, the three park rangers and the technician at the LMS have been employed regularly, while the procedures for the two new personnel (one from LMS and other from the Natural Capital Resource Center) are underway. Based on the information from the Municipality, these employments are expected to be completed by the end of the year or early in 2017. The personnel from LMS and the Natural Capital Resource Center are already contracted by the municipality but on a temporary basis, which needs to be transformed into permanent contracts. 9. The media coverage of the project still remains high, besides that the project is in the mature stages of implementation, and the number of ongoing activities is reducing over time. In order to better systematize and promote results, the project is working both on final publication and a documentary film. These products are expected to be completed by the end of 2016, along with a plan for their international and national promotion.

• Full transition toward municipal implementation modality is achieved following the complete staffing of the Sector on Environment, sustainability instruments are operational and UNDP-backed implementation phases-out • Wetland restoration activities in the Ezerani Nature Park are completed • Irrigation scheduling system is introduced based on agro-meteorological monitoring data and model development

The Municipality of Resen has taken full responsibility for the implementation of the project as planned. The newly created Sector on Environment incorporated the different systems established by UNDP throughout the project implementation lifespan (e.g., Lake Monitoring Station, management bodies of protected areas, biodegradable waste management system). The municipality was able to transform the key temporary employments into permanent professional positions in the Sector. The basic functioning of all systems has been backed by permanent financing instruments as a key sustainability pre-condition. UNDP was also able to facilitate the transition from the old to the new political structure in the municipality that was created after the local elections. The change of mayor and ruling political party didn’t influence the professional structures in the municipality, enabling continuity of earlier work.
Moreover, with the support of UNDP, the municipality is working on identifying follow-up complementary projects that will ensure continuation of the restoration efforts and strengthen ecosystem benefits (e.g., UNDP-implemented EU IPA funded project on Nature Protection/Protected Areas Management). One long-term possibility for funding local conservation action the municipality is actively working on is through the Prespa-Ohrid Nature Trust (PONT) that has expressed interest to build upon the achievements of the Lake Prespa Restoration Programme.
The wetland restoration activities in the Ezerani Nature Park were completed following multi-year planning and community involvement efforts, and resolution of a set of complex challenges – from land ownership-related issues to politically driven speculations about potential increase of the flood risk that intensified during repeated electoral processes. This first-of-its-kind projects of this type in the country and the wider region already started producing number of benefits for the ecosystem and the communities. The enhanced filtering function of the wetland against the upstream pressures (e.g., from diffuse pollution and sewage) will not only greatly protect the lake, but will also produce a number of ancillary ecosystem benefits (e.g., habitat diversity, flood attenuation).
Based on the recommendations of the earlier study on basin-scale irrigation options, the project has conceptualized on a decision-support system for irrigation scheduling that combines the use of the existing agro-meteorological monitoring stations and additional modeling work. The existing SMS and social media-based platforms are planned to used to inform farmers in a timely fashion about the time and dosage to apply water to crops. Considering the financial constraints (the project has entered its final stages of implementation), UNDP is working to mobilize funding from different sources to complete the software development work (e.g., through the project component implemented by the Municipality of Resen, or other UNDP-backed projects).
